bestBHT.bht: When Jesus advises his followers to not return for their garments in the field, it signifies the urgency of the situation. In ancient times, workers would leave their clothes behind while laboring, and Jesus's warning indicates the need for immediate action. The disciples must not even take the time to retrieve their outer garments, which were typically set aside during work. This aligns with historical accounts of people swiftly fleeing, without any opportunity to gather belongings. The imminent disaster makes it clear that there is no time to waste.

Albert Barnes: Return back to take his clothes - His clothes which, in 'working,' He had laid aside, or which, in fleeing, he should throw off as an encumbrance.
Clothes" here means the "outer" garment, commonly laid aside when men worked or ran.

These directions were followed. It is said that the Christians, warned by these predictions, fled from Jerusalem to Pella, and other places beyond the Jordan; so that there is not evidence that a single 'Christian' perished in Jerusalem - Eusebius, Hist. Eccl., lib. 3 chapter 6.
Archibald T. Robertson: In the field (εν τω αγρω). The peasant worked in his time and left his mantle at home then as now.
John Gill: Hence those words of Virgil: 'Nudus ara, sere nudus, hyems ignava colono.'

It is reported by the historian of Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus, that the messengers who were sent to him, from Minutius the consul, whom he had delivered from a siege, found him ploughing naked beyond the Tiber.
He might not go back for them, so sudden and swift should be the desolation.
